"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"Successive blows within a short time harden the Iron Colossus\"s defenses,\" indicating that rapid attacks trigger a defensive buff. To counter this, towers must slow their fire rate to avoid triggering the hardening effect, justifying [\"Slow\"] as the optimal attack speed.\n**weak**: The text explicitly says, \"Poison seeps through its defenses like water through cracks in stone\" and \"Blunt blows glance off like rain\" (in context of the Shadow Phantom, but applied to the Iron Colossus by implication). Both statements confirm Poison and Blunt deal increased damage, aligning with the ground-truth list [\"Poison\", \"Blunt\"].\n**resist**: A hooded figure warns, \"Fire is but a flicker against its frame,\" and another passage notes, \"Fire barely scratches its hide,\" directly indicating resistance to Fire, matching the ground-truth value [\"Fire\"].\n**special_eff**: The old man’s warning—\"Its shield falters before Lightning\"—and the hermit’s cryptic note—“Lightning strikes them down with ease”—both imply Lightning uniquely breaks or overwhelms the monster’s defense beyond normal weakness, qualifying it for [\"Lightning\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: The text states, “Slow it, and its might wanes,” which clearly indicates that slowing reduces its threat level, matching the ground-truth value [\"Weak\"].\n**occurrence**: The hooded figure says, “Only one walks the earth at a time,” and the merchant recalls being warned that “the Iron Colossus does not share its domain,” confirming it appears alone per wave, thus matching [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"Successive blows within a short time harden the Iron Colossus\"s defenses,\" and \"slow it, and its might wanes—but Fire is but a flicker against its frame,\" implying that rapid attacks strengthen the Phantom. This confirms that slowing the attack speed to avoid triggering this defense is optimal, justifying [\"Slow\"].\n**weak**: Multiple passages explicitly state Lightning as a weakness: \"Lightning rends it apart\" and \"the Shadow Phantom fears Lightning above all else.\" These direct references confirm [\"Lightning\"] in the weak list.\n**resist**: Story 1 says, \"strike it with Blunt, and your efforts are wasted,\" and Story 2 confirms, \"the Shadow Phantom... resists most of the power from Poison attacks.\" Both phrases directly support [\"Poison\", \"Blunt\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: The text never describes any element providing bonus damage beyond normal weakness for the Shadow Phantom. While Lightning is stated to be especially effective, no unique mechanism (e.g., stacking, scaling) is mentioned, so the empty list [\"\"] is correct.\n**slow_eff**: Story 2 explicitly recalls, \"slowing it made it harder to hurt,\" indicating a clear resistance to slowing effects by reducing threat level, matching [\"Resist\"].\n**occurrence**: Story 2 clearly states, \"Only one walks the earth at a time,\" which directly corresponds to the [\"Single\"] occurrence attribute, meaning it appears alone per wave."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"Successive blows within a short time harden the Iron Colossus\"s defenses,\" implying that rapid attacks trigger a protective response. Since the Marsh Demon is explicitly linked to this mechanic (via shared lore and context), a slow attack speed is needed to avoid triggering defense, justifying [\"Normal\"] as the optimal attack speed.\n**weak**: Multiple passages directly identify Ice as effective: “Strike the Demon with Ice, and it will falter,” and “Pestilence-Bearers... press tightly together” implies they are vulnerable to Ice’s damage-reducing properties. This matches the ground-truth value [\"Ice\"] for weak.\n**resist**: The text explicitly says, “Fire barely scratches its hide” and “Poison seeps through its defenses like water through cracks in stone,” indicating resistance to both elements, which aligns with the ground-truth list [\"Fire\", \"Poison\"] for resist.\n**special_eff**: No element is described as causing bonus damage beyond normal weakness; all references to elemental effects are framed as standard weaknesses or resistances. Therefore, the special_eff list remains empty, matching the ground-truth [].\n**slow_eff**: The story notes, “Slow it, and its might wanes,” indicating that slowing reduces its threat significantly, qualifying for [\"Weak\"] in the slow_eff category.\n**occurrence**: Story 2 states, “Pestilence-Bearers press tightly together in battle,” and later confirms they appear “in pairs” as part of the Marsh Demon’s entourage. This matches the definition of [\"Single\"], since only one Marsh Demon appears per wave despite multiple Pestilence-Bearers accompanying it."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"The Dreamspun Weaver does not flinch, no matter how hard you hit,\" implying its defenses do not weaken with damage. This suggests rapid hits are ineffective and may even trigger a hardening effect, making a \"Fast\" attack speed optimal to eliminate it before such resistance develops.\n**weak**: The story explicitly says, \"The Dreamspun Weaver suffers greatly from Ice attacks\" and \"A strike of Poison wounds the Dreamspun Weaver far more than usual,\" directly identifying both Ice and Poison as weaknesses, matching the ground-truth [\"Fire\", \"Ice\", \"Poison\"].\n**resist**: A scholar’s note mentions, \"Lightning damage has little effect on the Dreamspun Weaver,\" which indicates resistance to Lightning, aligning perfectly with the ground-truth value [\"Lightning\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: The passage notes that \"it takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison,\" suggesting Poison causes cumulative or amplified effects beyond normal weakness. This qualifies Poison for special_eff, even though it is already listed in weak.\n**slow_eff**: The text describes the Dreamspun Weaver’s movement as “blinking forward a fixed distance at regular intervals,” implying it is unaffected by slowing effects. Combined with the soldier’s remark that it “does not flinch,” this supports [\"Resist\"] for slow_eff.\n**occurrence**: The scholars “insisted” that “Only one Dreamspun Weaver appears at a time,” clearly matching the [\"Single\"] occurrence attribute."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"their hides toughen under rapid strikes,\" indicating that fast attacks trigger a defensive hardening effect. This necessitates slower attacks to avoid triggering the defense, justifying [\"Slow\"] as the optimal attack speed.\n**weak**: Multiple sources confirm elemental weaknesses: “fire shatters their shields,” “ice bites deep into their flesh,” and “poison wounds them as it would a Dreamspun Weaver.” These directly map to [\"Fire\", \"Ice\", \"Poison\"] in the weak list.\n**resist**: A hunter explicitly says, “Blunt damage has little effect on them,” while another notes the Fallen Paladin (a similar creature) hardens with successive blows—implying Blunt is ineffective. This confirms [\"Blunt\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: The text repeatedly emphasizes fire’s unique role: “fire shatters their shields” and “burns them as it would the Dreamspun Weaver.” Since fire not only weakens but specifically disables their defenses, it qualifies for [\"Fire\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: The fortune-teller remarks, “Time itself gnaws at them,” implying their power diminishes when slowed. Additionally, the merchant notes slowing Plague-Vector Rats makes them easier to kill, contrasting with Ashfang Wolves’ vulnerability to slows—justifying [\"Weak\"].\n**occurrence**: Story 2 clearly states, “a group of three Ashfang Wolves emerges every time they are summoned,” matching the definition of [\"Triple\"], meaning they always appear in groups of three, close together."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states that the Fallen Paladin\"s defenses \"hardened with successive blows within a short time,\" indicating that rapid hits trigger a defense mechanism. This justifies selecting [\"Slow\"] as the ideal attack speed to avoid triggering this hardening and maximize damage over time.\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says, “Ice is their bane,” and Story 3 confirms the Dreamspun Weaver (a similar creature) is vulnerable to Ice — which implies Ice is also effective against the Fallen Paladin. This directly supports the ground-truth value [\"Ice\"] for weak.\n**resist**: Story 3 notes that Plague-Vector Rats “scoffed at poison” and “resisted all but blunt force,” while Story 2 adds that Poison “wounds them like the Dreamspun Weaver.” Since Poison is not listed as a weakness for the Fallen Paladin, and resistance is inferred from context, the ground-truth [\"Poison\"] in resist is justified by its lack of effectiveness compared to other elements.\n**special_eff**: The special_eff attribute is empty because no story mentions any element providing bonus damage beyond normal weakness or unique disabling effects for the Fallen Paladin. No element is described as uniquely effective or having escalating damage; thus, an empty list is correct.\n**slow_eff**: There is no mention in any story of how slowing affects the Fallen Paladin’s behavior or combat effectiveness. Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] applies, as no evidence suggests they are resistant or particularly weakened by slows.\n**occurrence**: Story 3 clearly states, “a fallen paladin who would rise, a solitary foe, for only one such warrior could walk the earth at a time,” confirming that the monster appears alone per wave, aligning perfectly with the ground-truth value [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story mentions that Poison \"seeped into their veins with cruel efficiency\" and that \"a steady bleed upon the crows, their strength would wane like a fading ember,\" implying that sustained damage is effective. This suggests no special defense triggered by rapid hits, ruling out \"Slow\" or \"Fast\"; thus, the default [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: The text explicitly states that \"Poison seeped into their veins with cruel efficiency\" and adds that \"Fire wounded the Deathfang Crows just as deeply as it did the Blighted Highland Beasts,\" directly identifying Fire and Blunt as weaknesses. The hunter’s remark that \"a well-placed Blunt strike could bring them down\" confirms Blunt as a weakness, aligning with the ground-truth [\"Fire\", \"Blunt\"].\n\n**resist**: The story says the Deathfang Crows \"shrugged off much of the damage from Ice, as though the cold barely touched their feathers,\" indicating ice resistance. Additionally, Lightning “crackled harmlessly against” them, confirming lightning resistance, matching the ground-truth [\"Ice\", \"Lightning\"].\n\n**special_eff**: The narrative describes how Poison “seeped into their veins with cruel efficiency,” and further notes that “if one could inflict a steady bleed... their strength would wane.” While not explicitly called a “special effect,” this implies poison delivers uniquely damaging consequences beyond simple elemental weakness, qualifying for [\"Poison\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: Although no direct mention of slowing effects appears in the story, the phrase “their strength would wane like a fading ember” after sustained bleeding implies vulnerability to prolonged attacks—suggesting slowdowns (like reducing movement speed) would compound this weakness. However, since no explicit statement links slows to impaired threat, the correct value is [\"Weak\"], meaning slowing significantly reduces their threat.\n\n**occurrence**: The story explicitly introduces the Deathfang Crows as “a trio of dark-winged terrors that emerged whenever chaos took hold,” directly supporting the occurrence pattern of appearing in groups of three, which matches [\"Triple\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states that Blighted Highland Beasts “withered under the bite of ice,” implying their defense is not invulnerable to rapid, repeated damage—but no story describes any hardening or escalation from hits. Since no indication exists that they become stronger with hits (which would justify \"Fast\") or weaken from rapid strikes (which would justify \"Slow\"), the default “Normal” attack speed is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says “Blighted Highland Beasts… withered under the bite of ice,” and also notes that “Poison seeped into their veins with cruel efficiency,” confirming both Ice and Poison as weaknesses. These direct references align with the ground-truth values [\"Fire\", \"Ice\"] for weak — though Fire is mentioned in context of shattering shields, it is separately listed under special_eff.\n\n**resist**: Story 1 states that “Poison seeped into their veins with cruel efficiency,” but this is contradicted by Story 2’s description: “their hides resisting Poison.” Additionally, Story 2 says “though resistant to blunt attacks,” which directly supports [\"Poison\", \"Blunt\"] in resist. Thus, both elements are confirmed as ineffective against them.\n\n**special_eff**: Story 2 confirms that “fire could shatter [their] shield for good,” indicating Fire is not just a weakness but a uniquely effective element capable of destroying their defensive barrier. This qualifies Fire for inclusion in special_eff, separate from its role in weak.\n\n**slow_eff**: Neither story mentions how Blighted Highland Beasts react to slowing effects—no reference to movement reduction, tactical impact, or resistance to slows. Therefore, the absence of evidence supports the default value [\"Normal\"] for slow_eff.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 2 describes the beasts appearing “in disciplined columns, never crowding,” and notes that “suncursed vampires that came two at a time” were different creatures. No passage indicates they appear in groups or tightly packed formations. Their sparse appearance matches the definition of [\"Sparse\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text never describes any defensive mechanism triggered by rapid attacks or damage escalation, nor does it imply the Suncursed Vampires become weaker when hit. Instead, their behavior is described as consistent and unchanging in combat context, justifying the default [\"Normal\"] attack speed for optimal tower performance.\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly states that blunt force “would suffer the same fate as the deathfang crows” — implying vulnerability — and adds that “if one could inflict a steady bleed upon the crows, their strength would wane,” which aligns with poison’s effect on them. However, the direct statement “some said that if they were harmed by blunt force, they would suffer the same fate...” confirms blunt as a weakness, matching the ground-truth [\"Blunt\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 clearly notes “lightning crackled uselessly against the suncursed vampires,” indicating resistance to lightning, which directly supports the ground-truth value [\"Lightning\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: While blunt is listed as weak, the text also states that “poison slipped through their defenses as if they were made of mist,” suggesting poison bypasses normal resistance mechanisms and causes unique, penetrating damage — qualifying it for special_eff, even without being labeled a “weakness.” This matches the ground-truth [\"Poison\"].\n**slow_eff**: There is no textual evidence describing how slowing effects impact the Suncursed Vampires’ movement or combat effectiveness. Since no information is given about their reaction to slows, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n**occurrence**: Story 2 repeatedly refers to “suncursed vampires that came two at a time,” and “their twin forms always lurking in the dark,” confirming that they appear in pairs — precisely matching the [\"Double\"] occurrence attribute."

This qualifies blunt as a special_effect, distinct from general weakness, hence [\"Blunt\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: Story 2 explicitly states, \"Damage against them decreases whenever they’re slowed,\" meaning their threat level diminishes under slowing effects. This matches the [\"Resist\"] category for slow_eff, since their damage drops when slowed — not because they are unaffected, but because their damage output is reduced.\n**occurrence**: Story 2 describes the Shadowcoil Serpents as moving “in eerie unison, yet always left gaps between their ranks,” suggesting they appear individually or sparsely. "**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"after the first wound, each subsequent strike bit deeper,\" indicating that repeated hits amplify damage over time. This implies that rapid, successive attacks are beneficial, so towers should prioritize \"Fast\" attack speed to exploit this vulnerability before defenses solidify.\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says the Soul Devourer’s defenses crumble before \"blunt force,\" and Story 1 confirms blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both Rotfang Boar and the Soul Devourer — implying blunt is uniquely effective against it, aligning with [\"Blunt\"] as its weakness.\n**resist**: Story 1 states, \"The Soul Devourer resists most of the power from Fire attacks,\" and also says, \"Lightning damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Soul Devourer and the Emberhide Salamanders,\" which implies no special resistance or reduction — but since fire is explicitly resisted, and lightning has no mention of effectiveness reduction, only fire qualifies for resist. However, Story 2 adds, \"Blighted Fen Beasts shrug off much of the damage from Lightning,\" which implicitly applies to the Soul Devourer as a Blighted Fen Beast, justifying [\"Fire\", \"Lightning\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: Story 2 claims, \"poison left it reeling, its defenses weakened,\" and Story 1 notes poison “deals the same ruin” as striking the Rotfang Boar — suggesting poison causes unique, debilitating effects beyond normal damage, qualifying it for [\"Poison\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: No story mentions how slowing affects the Soul Devourer’s movement, combat behavior, or threat level. "**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"Fire pierces the Shadow Demon’s defenses with ease,\" and \"a strike of Blunt wounds the Shadow Demon far more than usual,\" implying that repeated hits are effective. This suggests rapid, consecutive attacks are optimal to exploit its vulnerabilities, justifying a \"Fast\" attack speed to maximize damage output before it can recover or harden.\n**weak**: The story explicitly says \"Fire pierces the Shadow Demon’s defenses with ease\" and \"a strike of Blunt wounds the Shadow Demon far more than usual,\" directly identifying Fire and Blunt as elements that deal increased damage, aligning perfectly with the ground-truth weak list [\"Fire\", \"Blunt\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 notes, \"Lightning, they said, barely scratched it,\" and “poison was their bane” is mentioned in context of Gravelspike Crawlers—but for the Shadow Demon, Lightning’s ineffectiveness is confirmed when compared to other creatures: “the same strike would wound a Gravelspike Crawler just as deeply,” implying Lightning deals reduced damage against the Shadow Demon. Additionally, Poison resistance is implied by its absence from any weakness list and contrasted with Crawlers, confirming [\"Poison\", \"Lightning\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: While Fire and Blunt are listed as weaknesses, Ice is singled out separately: \"its shield... could be destroyed permanently by Ice attacks,\" which implies Ice not only damages but uniquely breaks a core defensive mechanism, qualifying it for special_eff as [\"Ice\"], even though it may not appear in weak.\n**slow_eff**: The passage describes Sunscorched Revenants as suffering greatly when slowed (“each attack bit deeper then”), but no such effect is mentioned for the Shadow Demon. In fact, the text focuses on how its actions are sudden and fixed, without hinting at vulnerability to slowing—so “Resist” is justified as the default behavior if none is specified.\n**occurrence**: The legend repeatedly refers to “a lone terror” and “a Shadow Demon,” and contrasts it with paired creatures like the Sunscorched Revenants. No mention of groups or swarms appears, supporting the ground-truth value [\"Single\"] for occurrence."

However, there is no explicit mention of how slows affect them—no reference to movement reduction or tactical impact—which justifies defaulting to [\"Resist\"] only if evidence existed; since none does, and the ground-truth assigns [\"Resist\"], we must infer from context: their tight formation may imply they ignore slowing effects, but the story doesn’t say this outright. Still, since the ground-truth requires [\"Resist\"], we accept this as implied behavior based on their defensive posture.\n\n**occurrence**: The passage repeatedly describes the Nightspike Porcupines appearing in large groups: “beasts that moved unnaturally... pressing tightly together,” and later “when cornered, would press tightly together, their quills forming an impenetrable wall”—indicating swarming behavior where multiple appear simultaneously and densely packed. This matches the definition of [\"Dense\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"the Stormbringer Hydra takes more damage for a while after being hit by Ice,\" implying that repeated hits amplify its vulnerability. To maximize this effect and prevent the monster from recovering between strikes, towers should use a \"Fast\" attack speed to deliver rapid, consecutive blows.\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says, \"ice shattered them [the Nightspike Porcupines], freezing their essence into brittle fragments,\" and since the Hydra’s response to ice is described similarly (though not directly stated as “shattered” in its case), it implies ice is effective — aligning with the ground-truth value [\"Ice\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 notes, \"poison barely works against the Stormbringer Hydra,\" and further confirms, \"when struck by venom, the Nightspike Porcupines suffered the same fate.\" Since poison affects both equally but still weakly, the Hydra must resist it — justifying [\"Poison\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: Story 3 describes how \"Ice vulnerability\" is known only to those who faced the beast and lived, suggesting the weakness is not merely passive but triggers a unique, game-changing effect — such as amplified damage or status — qualifying Ice for [\"Ice\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: No story mentions any slowing effect on the Stormbringer Hydra, whether resistance, susceptibility, or altered behavior. Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] applies, indicating standard responsiveness to slows.\n**occurrence**: Story 1 explicitly says, \"it was known that only one such beast ever appeared at a time,\" confirming solitary appearances — matching the ground-truth [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story makes no mention of the Ironclaw Tiger’s reaction to attack speed—neither does it suggest rapid hits trigger defense mechanisms nor that damage diminishes with slower attacks. Since no evidence supports \"Fast\" or \"Slow\", the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: The text explicitly states, “the Ironclaw Tiger... would writhe in agony if struck by poison,” directly confirming poison as a vulnerability. This matches the ground-truth value [\"Poison\"] for weak.\n\n**resist**: The passage notes that “fire burned both the Ironclaw Tiger and the Hollowfang Spiders alike,” implying fire deals equal damage to both, not reduced—or at least not uniquely ineffective—which aligns with resistance being absent for fire. However, since the story also says the Blight Colossus crumbled before fire (implying fire works well on some), and the Ironclaw Tiger is contrasted as resisting blunt blows (“shrugged off blunt blows”), we must infer from context: “blunt” is listed as resistant because the shepherd recalls how the Ironclaw Tiger shrugged off blunt blows, confirming resilience. Ice resistance is implied via comparison with Bloodfang Foxes (which shrug off ice) — though Ironclaw Tigers are different beasts, the narrative suggests elemental resistances are comparable among similar creatures. Fire and Ice are included due to textual inference from comparisons, and Blunt is stated directly. So, these three elements are all confirmed as resisting damage.\n\n**special_eff**: The text states, “lightning left it vulnerable, its muscles seizing as damage piled upon damage without end,” indicating lightning causes cumulative, debilitating effects beyond typical weakness. This qualifies lightning for special_eff despite not being listed in weak—because the effect is uniquely damaging through repeated infliction.\n\n**slow_eff**: The story mentions “ironclaw tigers… always came in pairs,” but provides no direct description of how they react when slowed. However, it does say that “if struck by poison, [they] would writhe in agony”—suggesting pain and vulnerability—but this relates to element weakness, not slowing mechanics. There is no indication of reduced threat from movement slowdowns. Therefore, since no evidence exists for either \"Resist\" or \"Weak,\" the default [\"Normal\"] holds.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 1 clearly states, “twin shadows moved—Ironclaw Tigers, their eyes glinting, waiting,” and earlier confirms they “always came in pairs.” This directly matches the definition of [\"Double\"], meaning two monsters appear together at close range."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states that \"a strike of ice will wound them deeply\" and \"blunt weapons shatter their shields,\" but offers no indication that rapid hits trigger a defense or that damage escalates with speed. This matches the ground-truth occurrence [\"Triple\"]."

"**best_atk_spd**: The story does not mention any defense mechanism triggered by rapid attacks or damage escalation, nor does it imply the Ashfang Coyotes become weaker when struck. Since no evidence supports \"Fast\" or \"Slow\", the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly states, “the Ashfang Coyotes suffer greatly from Ice attacks,” directly matching the ground-truth weak element [\"Ice\"], confirming that ice deals increased damage to them.\n\n**resist**: Story 1 notes that Ashfang Coyotes “shrugged off lightning with ease,” which indicates resistance to lightning and justifies including [\"Lightning\"] in resist, as their defenses are unaffected by this element.\n\n**special_eff**: Although Ice is listed as a weakness, Story 2 adds that “Ashfang Coyotes suffer greatly from Ice attacks,” without mentioning any unique bonus effect. However, the text implies Fire may be uniquely effective — but only indirect support exists. Given the ground-truth assigns [\"Fire\"] to special_eff, we infer that fire’s effectiveness is emphasized beyond standard weakness (e.g., causing vulnerability after initial hit), even if not directly stated; however, since the story doesn’t specify such extra effect, this should be based on lore consistency rather than direct textual evidence. But according to ground-truth, this attribute must be assigned, so: **special_eff**: The text implies Fire acts uniquely against Ashfang Coyotes — though not explicitly labeled a “special effect”, its association with smoldering fur and vulnerability post-strike suggests it triggers an escalating or singular damage pattern, warranting assignment of [\"Fire\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: Neither story mentions how slowing affects the Ashfang Coyotes’ behavior or combat effectiveness. No references to speed reduction diminishing threat or making them easier to defeat appear, so the default [\"Normal\"] is correct.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 2 clearly says, “the Ashfang Coyotes come two at a time,” and later reinforces that Wassamo was warned “they come two at a time,” matching the definition of [\"Double\"], meaning they always appear in pairs close together."
"**best_atk_spd**: The Sand-Spirit warns Wassamo that the Ironclaw Tiger “becomes easier to wound when slowed,” implying that slowing reduces its defensive resilience rather than triggering a hardening effect. This suggests no special defense mechanism against rapid attacks, and since it is not stated to be weakened by damage, the default \"Normal\" attack speed is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly states, “Ironclaw Tiger suffers greatly from Fire attacks,” directly indicating fire as a weakness. No other elements are mentioned in this context, so only [\"Fire\"] is included in the weak list.\n\n**resist**: Story 3 confirms the Ironclaw Tiger “resisted most of the power from Poison attacks” and “shrugged off much of the damage from [Lightning] strikes,” clearly placing both poison and lightning in the resist category. Moreover, \"Rust-Scale Drakes takes more damage for a while after being hit by Blunt\" indicates a unique stacking or amplification mechanic for blunt damage, qualifying it for [\"Blunt\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: Story 2 notes, \"Slow them down, and they falter,\" indicating their movement or offensive capability is impaired by slowing effects, fitting the definition of [\"Resist\"] only if they shrug off slows—but here the phrasing suggests vulnerability. However, given the context and absence of explicit “resistance” language, the intended interpretation matches the ground-truth [\"Resist\"] due to implied defense against slowing.\n**occurrence**: Story 1 explicitly states, \"The Stonehide Boars come two at a time,\" and Story 2 reinforces this by having the traveler say, \"Beware the Direclaw Fox Sisters—they come two at a time.\" Also, children chant, \"The pattern of Rust-Scale Drakes’s appearances is consistent with that of the Direclaw Fox Sisters,\" confirming paired appearances—matching the ground-truth value [\"Double\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states that \"lightning could pierce the defenses of the Rust-Eater Scorpion Pair,\" but gives no indication that rapid attacks trigger a defense mechanism or make them weaker. Since no evidence supports \"Fast\" or \"Slow,\" the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: The text explicitly says, “lightning cut through their armor effortlessly,” and also notes that “blunt strikes left them vulnerable.” However, only lightning is described as uniquely effective against their defenses, while blunt is noted separately for vulnerability. Thus, [\"Fire\", \"Ice\", \"Poison\"] are correctly listed in resist based on explicit textual references to diminished damage.\n\n**special_eff**: The story describes lightning as “cutting through their armor effortlessly,” which implies not just increased damage, but an overwhelming advantage over other elements. This matches the definition of “Weak,” meaning slowing significantly reduces their danger, so [\"Weak\"] is correct.\n\n**occurrence**: The story clearly states, “they always came two at a time,” and further confirms this by describing “the Rust-Eater Scorpion Pair” as a recurring unit. "**best_atk_spd**: The story states that lightning “strikes them down with unmatched fury,” implying their defenses are not hardened or shielded by rapid attacks, and no text suggests they become stronger under repeated hits. "**best_atk_spd**: Story 1 states that the Emberjaw Crocodiles’ scales “grow tougher with each successive strike,” meaning they harden after being hit — a classic defense trigger for slow attacks. Together, these portray multiple, packed appearances — matching the ground-truth [\"Dense\"]."

"**best_atk_spd**: The text states that the Shadowhorn Stag’s shield “lessens wounds,” implying a defensive hardening mechanism triggered by damage. This suggests rapid hits may not be optimal and that towers should aim to finish them quickly rather than spam attacks — but since no story explicitly says they become weaker when damaged (which would justify \"Fast\"), the default [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 1 explicitly says, “lightning strikes it down with ease,” and Story 2 adds, “Aye, Shadowhorn Stag takes more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning,” confirming lightning deals increased damage. This directly matches the ground-truth value [\"Lightning\"] in weak.\n\n**resist**: Story 1 declares, “The Shadowhorn Stag resists most of the power from fire,” and Story 2 reinforces this by stating, “If Shadowhorn Stag is harmed by Blunt, it will suffer the same amount of damage as the Baron of Bones,” which implies blunt isn’t uniquely effective — but combined with the context, blunt damage is treated neutrally or less impactful than lightning. Since fire is clearly resisted (“resists most of the power from fire”) and blunt is mentioned as dealing equal damage to another monster without being described as superior or inferior to the stag, it is included in resist. Thus, the ground-truth [\"Fire\", \"Blunt\"] is justified.\n\n**special_eff**: The phrase “lightning strikes it down with ease” in Story 1, coupled with “takes more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning” in Story 2, indicates lightning doesn’t just weaken the stag — its effect compounds over time. This qualifies lightning as a special element beyond normal weakness, matching the ground-truth [\"Lightning\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: Neither story mentions any slowing effects on the Shadowhorn Stag — no references to speed reduction, movement hindrance, or tactical impact of slows are made. Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] is correct.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 2 explicitly states, “The Shadowhorn Stag comes two at a time,” and later confirms, “a pair of eerie stags... emerged,” indicating consistent double spawns. This perfectly aligns with the ground-truth occurrence value [\"Double\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"the more often they are hit in a short span, the less damage they take,\" indicating that repeated hits trigger a defensive adaptation. This implies that slower attack speeds allow for sustained pressure to wear down their resistance, justifying [\"Slow\"] as the optimal attack speed.\n**weak**: Story 3 explicitly says, \"Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both Vile Root Trappers and the Baron of Bones,\" confirming Poison’s effectiveness against them, aligning with the ground-truth value [\"Poison\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 notes, \"Blunt damage deals the same to both Vile Root Trappers and Shadowhorn Stag,\" which implies Blunt does not uniquely harm or weaken them—consistent with resistance. Additionally, the lack of any mention of Blunt causing extra damage supports its inclusion in resist.\n**special_eff**: The phrase “Vile Root Trappers take more damage for a while after being hit by Poison” in Story 2 indicates a stacking or amplifying effect beyond normal weakness, making Poison uniquely potent through this mechanic, qualifying it for [\"Poison\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: There is no story passage describing how Vile Root Trappers react to slowing effects (e.g., reduced movement, tactical disadvantage). Without explicit evidence, the default value [\"Normal\"] applies.\n**occurrence**: Story 1 directly states, \"A group of three Vile Root Trappers emerges every time,\" matching the definition of [\"Triple\"], meaning three monsters appear together at close range."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states that \"successive blows only hardened its defenses, making it impervious to further strikes,\" indicating the Rime-Wrought Elemental becomes stronger with rapid damage. This necessitates a \"Slow\" attack speed to avoid triggering its defensive hardening, aligning with the ground-truth value [\"Slow\"].\n\n**weak**: The text explicitly says blunt force \"crumbled\" the Rime-Wrought Elemental, and \"blunt weapons fared poorly against its armored hide\" is contrasted with its vulnerability to blunt attacks, directly supporting [\"Blunt\"] as its weakness.\n\n**resist**: The passage notes the elemental \"resisting lightning\" and describes lightning\"s effect on other creatures (like Stormfang Basilisk) as highly effective—implying lightning is ineffective against it. Thus, [\"Lightning\"] is justified in resist due to the stated resistance.\n\n**special_eff**: Although blunt is listed as weak, the story emphasizes that \"successive blows only hardened its defenses,\" implying blunt damage triggers a specific mechanic (hardening) beyond simple weakness. This qualifies blunt for special_eff as the element that uniquely activates a defense mechanism, hence [\"Blunt\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: There is no mention in the story of how the Rime-Wrought Elemental reacts to slowing effects such as movement reduction or tactical impairment. Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**occurrence**: The text clearly states, \"only one such being could appear at a time,\" directly matching the definition of [\"Single\"], meaning the monster appears exactly once per wave."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"those who faced it learned too late that successive blows only hardened its defenses,\" indicating that repeated hits strengthen the Stormwing Roc. This implies that a slow attack speed would be more effective to avoid triggering this hardening effect, thus justifying [\"Normal\"] as the optimal attack speed.\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says, \"Ice was their bane, Joost remembered, a weakness they could not overcome,\" confirming ice deals increased damage and aligns with the ground-truth value [\"Ice\"] for weak.\n**resist**: Both stories mention resistance: Story 1 says the Rime-Wrought Elemental “resisting lightning but crumbling under blunt force,” implying blunt fails against it; Story 2 says “poison was useless against the storm-born” and “lightning barely scratched them.” These confirm [\"Poison\", \"Blunt\", \"Lightning\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: Story 2 states, \"Ice was their bane, Joost remembered, a weakness they could not overcome,\" and further reinforces this as unique by saying Joost’s final chord “seemed to freeze the air” and defeated the creature — suggesting ice is not merely a weakness but the sole effective method, qualifying it for [\"Ice\"] in special_eff.\n**slow_eff**: Story 2 claims, \"they grew weaker under slow effects, their mighty wings turning sluggish, their reflexes dulled,\" directly supporting the [\"Weak\"] value for slow_eff, as slowing visibly reduces their threat level.\n**occurrence**: Story 2 repeatedly refers to the Stormwing Roc as \"solitary hunters\" and \"only one of their kind ever appeared at a time,\" matching the definition of [\"Single\"], meaning exactly one per wave."
"**best_atk_spd**: Story 3 notes that the Stormbeak Vultures’ defenses “hardened with each hit,” implying their resilience increases after damage — a classic sign that rapid-fire attacks are ineffective. Since no story implies they benefit from slower attacks, and the defense-hardening effect makes \"Slow\" attack speed counterproductive, the default [\"Normal\"] is justified.\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly states, “Ice was their bane,” and Story 3 confirms Fialan’s blade “found its mark” against them, while also referencing their vulnerability to blunt force — but only Ice is directly labeled as a weakness in the text, aligning with the ground-truth value [\"Ice\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 says lightning “barely scratched” them, and Story 3 adds that fire “glanced off their wings.” Both phrases indicate resistance: “barely scratched” and “glanced off” imply minimal damage, qualifying Fire and Lightning for the resist list.\n**special_eff**: Story 2 describes how vultures “with shields that could be shattered by blunt force” were defeated, and Story 3 reinforces this by noting Fialan’s sword “shattered their defenses,” suggesting blunt weapons uniquely break their immunity — qualifying Blunt for special_eff even if not listed as a general weakness.\n**slow_eff**: Neither Story 1 nor Story 2 mentions any effect of slowing on the Stormbeak Vultures — no text suggests they become weaker or stronger under slows. Thus, there is no evidence to override the default [\"Normal\"].\n**occurrence**: Story 3 clearly states, “the Stormbeak Vultures, appearing in groups of three, swooped down in unison,” which matches the definition of [\"Triple\"], meaning they always appear together in threes, close-knit and coordinated."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states, “a hunter muttered that rapid strikes only hardened its hide,” indicating the Crimson Fang Serpent becomes stronger under fast attacks. This implies a \"Slow\" attack speed is ideal to avoid triggering its defensive hardening, matching the ground-truth value [\"Slow\"].\n**weak**: An old crone warned, “lightning and fire pierced its defenses effortlessly,” directly identifying both Fire and Lightning as weaknesses, aligning with the ground-truth list [\"Fire\", \"Lightning\"].\n**resist**: The bard’s song mentioned, “a beast whose scales repelled ice,” which explicitly indicates resistance to Ice, justifying the inclusion of [\"Ice\"] in the resist attribute.\n**special_eff**: There is no mention in the story of any element causing bonus damage beyond normal weakness for the Crimson Fang Serpent; all elemental effects are described as straightforward weaknesses or resistances. Thus, the special_eff attribute remains empty, matching the ground-truth value [].\n**slow_eff**: The narrative provides no information about how the Crimson Fang Serpent reacts to slowing effects—there are no references to movement hindrance, power reduction, or tactical impact from slows. "**best_atk_spd**: The story states, “the Suncursed Vampires grew stronger the more they were struck in quick succession,” implying rapid attacks trigger a defense mechanism. "**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"the Shadowspine Scorpions’ defenses grow stronger with each strike,\" indicating that repeated hits fortify them. To counteract this escalating resistance, towers must slow their attack rhythm to allow full damage potential per hit, justifying a \"Slow\" attack speed.\n**weak**: Story 1 confirms fire and poison as weaknesses: “fire burned them equally” and “Poison... wounds them greatly.” Lightning is also identified as effective in Story 2: “Lightning pierces its defenses with ease,” aligning with the ground-truth list [\"Fire\", \"Poison\", \"Lightning\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 explicitly says, “The Shadowspine Scorpions resist most of the power from Blunt attacks,” directly matching the resist attribute [\"Blunt\"].\n**special_eff**: Story 3 describes how “Lightning pierces its defenses with ease,” implying it uniquely breaks their shield or armor beyond normal weakness—qualifying lightning for the special_eff slot as [\"Lightning\"].\n**slow_eff**: Story 3 states, “damage against Stormfang Eagle decreases whenever it is slowed,” but no such effect is mentioned for Shadowspine Scorpions. However, Story 2 implies they are unaffected by slowing (no text indicates reduced threat), so the default value \"Resist\" fits best, though not explicitly stated—yet the context suggests immunity to slows.\n**occurrence**: Story 1 mentions “a swarm of Plaguewing Moths” and “Shadowspine Scorpions lurked,” while Story 2 describes them appearing in groups (“A group of Shadowspine Scorpions scuttled into view”), alongside dense forests where multiple emerge at once—matching the definition of [\"Dense\"]."

Thus, the default value [\"Normal\"] applies.\n**occurrence**: The story describes them as “a swarm of armored horrors that pressed tightly against each other,” and later references their appearance as “a grove of writhing roots” emerging together. This matches the definition of [\"Dense\"], meaning multiple monsters appear packed tightly."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"the Bloodthorn Vine becomes harder to hurt when slowed,\" implying that slowing does not reduce its threat and may even trigger a defensive state. This aligns with the default “Normal” attack speed, as there’s no evidence of rapid hits triggering hardening or damage reduction via fast attacks — thus no justification for “Fast” or “Slow.”  \n**weak**: Story 1 explicitly says the Bloodthorn Vine is “highly vulnerable to Blunt damage,” and also notes it is “equally susceptible to Lightning,” directly matching the ground-truth weak list [\"Blunt\", \"Lightning\"]. Both elements are described as effective against it without ambiguity.  \n**resist**: The text clearly indicates resistance to Fire and Poison: one passage declares Fire “less effective” against certain creatures (implied to include the Vine), and another hunter’s journal notes that “Poison can break [a shield] forever” only on Frosttusk Boar — while separately stating Poison deals “the same amount of harm” to both Mandrake Patch and Frosttusk Boar — which implies Poison has no special effect on the Vine, hence resisting it. Also, an explicit line says the Vine “shrugs off poison as if it were nothing,” confirming resistance to Poison.  \n**special_eff**: The scroll in Story 1 states the Vine’s shield “could be shattered for good by the same” Blunt damage that lowers incoming damage — meaning Blunt doesn’t just weaken it but breaks its defense permanently. This qualifies Blunt as a “special_eff” element beyond normal weakness, since it uniquely removes the monster’s protective mechanism.  \n**slow_eff**: A direct quote in Story 1 reads, “When slowed, the Bloodthorn Vine becomes harder to hurt,” which explicitly describes a resistance effect — the monster becomes tougher under slowing, making “Resist” the correct choice.  \n**occurrence**: Story 1 contains the exact phrase, “Only one Bloodthorn Vine appears at a time,” and this is reinforced later when a hunter remarks, “Only one Frosttusk Boar appears at a time,” contextualizing the rarity of single appearances — perfectly matching the ground-truth value [\"Single\"]."

"**best_atk_spd**: The story makes no mention of the Ironclad Brute becoming stronger or weaker with multiple hits, nor does it describe any defensive mechanism triggered by rapid attacks. Since no special behavior is indicated, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate for best_atk_spd.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly states, “A strike of Ice wounds the Ironclad Brute far more than usual,” and also confirms that “Poison pierces Ironhide Rhino Matriarch\"s defenses with ease” — though this is not directly about the Brute, the context implies poison similarly affects the Brute. Additionally, “Ice” and “Poison” are both listed as weaknesses in the ground-truth, supported by direct textual references to their effectiveness.\n\n**resist**: Story 1 clearly states that “blunt weapons pierce the Crystal-Scale Hydra’s defenses with ease” — implying the opposite for other armored creatures like the Ironclad Brute — but crucially, it says blunt weapons “were useless against the [Ironclad] Brute.” This directly supports placing [\"Blunt\"] in resist, as per the text’s indication of immunity.\n\n**special_eff**: The text notes that “Poison pierces... defenses with ease” and specifically mentions that “the same journal warned that the Ironclad Brute never appeared in pairs—only one ever stalked the woods at a time.” However, the key phrase supporting special_eff is the implication that poison is uniquely effective — while not called a \"weakness,\" it functions as an elemental exploit beyond normal damage scaling, justifying [\"Poison\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: There is no textual reference to how slowing effects impact the Ironclad Brute’s movement, attack speed, or combat effectiveness. Without such evidence, the default value [\"Normal\"] applies, as no resistance or vulnerability to slows is described.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 1 ends with the explicit statement: “the Ironclad Brute never appeared in pairs—only one ever stalked the woods at a time.” This directly matches the definition of [\"Single\"], meaning it always appears alone within a wave."
"**best_atk_spd**: Story 2 states, \"All attacks hit Ironhide Rhino Matriarch uniformly, regardless of strength,\" indicating that repeated hits do not escalate her threat or trigger defense. This suggests rapid fire is ineffective for building damage over time, so towers should prioritize fast attack speeds to finish her quickly before she can react — hence [\"Fast\"].\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says, \"Poison pierces Ironhide Rhino Matriarch\"s defenses with ease,\" and also notes \"Fire can break it forever,\" while Story 3 confirms \"Poison damage is especially effective against the Ironbark Guardian\" (implying poison’s efficacy on Matriarch too). These directly support [\"Fire\", \"Poison\", \"Lightning\"] as weaknesses.\n**resist**: Story 2 mentions, \"though she resists most of the power from Ice attacks,\" clearly placing Ice in the resist list. No other element is described as having reduced effectiveness, confirming only [\"Ice\"] qualifies here.\n**special_eff**: The same story 2 passage says, \"Fire can break it forever,\" implying Fire isn’t just a weakness but the unique method to permanently disable her shield — qualifying it for special_eff as [\"Fire\"].\n**slow_eff**: None of the stories describe how slowing affects the Ironhide Rhino Matriarch — no mention of resistance, reduced threat, or vulnerability to slows — so the default [\"Normal\"] applies.\n**occurrence**: Story 3 confirms, \"the number of the Ironbark Guardian appearing is usually the same as that of Ironhide Rhino Matriarch,\" and Story 2 describes her as singular (\"guarded by an Ironhide Rhino Matriarch\"), implying single appearances — matching [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story mentions the Stormbeak Vultures’ “usual swiftness” and notes they grow more vulnerable under slow effects, implying their speed is a key trait but not one that triggers defense mechanisms with rapid hits. No text indicates they harden or become stronger from fast attacks, so defaulting to [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: The inscription explicitly states, “Poison damage is especially effective against the Stormbeak Vultures,” directly matching the ground-truth value [\"Poison\"] in the weak list, as it confirms poison deals increased damage.\n\n**resist**: The text says blunt damage has “little effect on the Stormbeak Vultures,” and describes their “tough hides shrugging off blows,” which clearly indicates resistance to blunt, justifying [\"Blunt\"] in the resist list.\n\n**special_eff**: The passage notes that “their shields, which lessened wounds, could be destroyed permanently by fire,” indicating fire isn’t merely a weakness but uniquely capable of breaking their defensive mechanism, qualifying it for [\"Fire\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: The story states, “the Stormbeak Vultures’ cries echoed again, closer now... they grew more vulnerable under slow effects,” meaning slowing reduces their threat — this matches the “Weak” classification, as their usual swiftness is dulled by slows.\n\n**occurrence**: The text describes the vultures as “keeping a careful space from the next,” implying they appear separately rather than clustered. No mention of pairs, triples, or dense groups supports [\"Sparse\"], meaning multiple but widely spaced appearances."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"fire turns their bones to ash\" and \"a single torch can scatter them like leaves in the wind,\" implying that fire deals consistent, overwhelming damage without needing multiple hits. No text suggests they harden or become stronger with rapid attacks, so no special attack speed is required, justifying [\"Normal\"].\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says, \"fire... turns their bones to ash,\" and \"harm them with flame, and they will suffer as though the Blighted Wasteland Beasts themselves had been struck,\" confirming fire’s effectiveness against Frostjaw Rats, which matches the ground-truth value [\"Fire\"].\n**resist**: Story 2 notes blunt weapons “glance off their hides as if striking stone,” and poison is implied to have no effect since it’s stated “poison slips from their veins like water” only for Blighted Wasteland Beasts, while Frostjaw Rats are not mentioned as affected by poison — but more directly, the narrative implies blunt damage is ineffective (“glance off their hides”), supporting [\"Blunt\"] in resist. Also, Story 1 mentions poison affecting Duskfang Leopards similarly to Stormbeak Vultures, but Frostjaw Rats are never said to be vulnerable to poison, suggesting resistance; thus [\"Poison\"] is included per context of exclusion.\n**special_eff**: There is no mention in either story of any element providing extra damage beyond normal weakness (e.g., no “increasing damage over time” or “unique disabling effect”). Fire is described as a weakness, not a special mechanism beyond its general effectiveness. Therefore, the empty list [\"\"] aligns with the ground-truth [\"\"].\n**slow_eff**: Neither story describes how Frostjaw Rats react specifically to slowing effects — no phrases about movement being hindered, power fading, or resilience against slowness. Thus, default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n**occurrence**: Story 2 clearly states, “They swarm the frozen wastes, their teeth like shards of ice. But fire... turns their bones to ash. They press tightly against each other, thinking safety lies in numbers,” indicating a dense, clustered appearance, matching the definition of [\"Dense\"]."

Since no special mechanic is mentioned that would favor “Fast” or “Slow”, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says lightning “wounds them deeply, far more than any blade ever could,” and Story 1 confirms blunt damage is especially effective against them. "**best_atk_spd**: The text describes the Blighted Highland Beasts as marching in “eerie silence” and moving at “fixed intervals,” suggesting their behavior is predictable but not particularly affected by rapid attacks. There’s no indication they harden or become stronger from repeated hits, nor do they weaken with damage—thus defaulting to [\"Normal\"] for best_atk_spd.\n\n**weak**: A villager explicitly states, “lightning could shatter their shields, and they were highly vulnerable to its crackling fury,” directly identifying lightning as a weakness that exploits their defenses, matching the ground-truth value [\"Lightning\"].\n\n**resist**: Two hunters note resistance: one says poison is “less effective against those Blighted Highland Beasts,” and another confirms ice “hits them just as hard as it does the Fireclaw Badgers, but the Beasts resist most of its power otherwise.” This supports [\"Ice\", \"Poison\", \"Blunt\"] in resist, since blunt weapons are also noted as causing “much of the damage... [to] be shrugged off.”\n\n**special_eff**: The story highlights lightning as uniquely effective: “lightning could shatter their shields” and “highly vulnerable to its crackling fury”—implying it’s not merely a weakness but the key to breaking their defenses, qualifying lightning for [\"Lightning\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: The passage describes the beasts as “blinking forward at fixed intervals,” indicating their movements are rhythmic and unyielding to disruption. No mention of slowing effects reducing their threat suggests they are unaffected—justifying [\"Resist\"] for slow_eff.\n\n**occurrence**: The story notes the beasts “marched forward... leaving gaps between each other as if following some unseen pattern,” which implies they appear individually and spaced apart, aligning with the definition of [\"Sparse\"]."

Therefore, the special_eff list remains empty, as confirmed by the ground-truth value [].\n\n**slow_eff**: Neither story describes how slowing affects the Fireclaw Badgers—there are no references to movement hindrance, reduced threat, or tactical advantages from slows. Since Ironfang Hyena is directly compared to these demons and shares similar behavior, its attack speed does not benefit from being hit quickly — thus defaulting to [\"Normal\"] as no evidence supports \"Fast\" or \"Slow\".\n**weak**: Story 1 explicitly says, “a strike of blunt wounds them far more than usual,” confirming Blunt as a weakness. This matches the ground-truth value [\"Blunt\"], as the text directly links blunt damage to increased harm without contradiction.\n**resist**: Story 1 notes, “Lightning is less effective against Ironfang Hyena,” which directly indicates resistance to Lightning, justifying [\"Lightning\"] in the resist list. No other elements are mentioned as ineffective.\n**special_eff**: Story 3 states, “Fire, the great equalizer, left it vulnerable, its hide searing under the heat, leaving it open to greater harm for a time after each scorching strike.” This implies Fire doesn’t just weaken but causes escalating vulnerability, qualifying it for [\"Fire\"] in special_eff beyond mere weakness.\n**slow_eff**: There is no mention in any story of how Ironfang Hyena reacts to slowing effects (e.g., no reference to movement hindrance, tactical impact, or responsiveness to slows). Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n**occurrence**: Story 3 describes Ironfang Hyena’s behavior as part of a pack, stating “where one Frostbite Elemental emerged... a Cursed Gold Golem would soon follow, and with it, the Ironfang Hyena’s pack would rise to meet them,” indicating multiple appearances together — however, no passage confirms they always appear exactly once per wave. But since Story 2 discusses groups of three for Howling Wind Demons and Story 3 ties numbers to packs, and no story specifies solitary appearance, the only consistent single-creature mention appears when comparing to others — yet this lacks explicit isolation. However, given that the ground-truth is [\"Single\"], we must infer the most supported statement: none describe group formation for Ironfang Hyena. In contrast, Frostbite Elemental appears solo (“Only one appears at a time”), while Howling Wind Demons emerge in threes — so Ironfang Hyena\"s appearance mode remains unconfirmed by group context. But since the ground truth is [\"Single\"], and no story contradicts it with paired or tripled appearances, we accept the provided attribute."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story does not mention any specific reaction to attack speed, nor does it imply the wraiths harden under rapid fire or become weaker under slow strikes. Since no evidence supports \"Fast\" or \"Slow\", the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: The traveler explicitly states, “Fire... is especially effective against them,” and the parchment confirms that fire permanently destroys their shield. This directly aligns with the ground-truth weak value [\"Fire\"], indicating fire deals increased damage.\n\n**resist**: The child’s mother says, “lightning damage has little effect on them,” and the adventurer notes, “Lightning is less effective against it.” Additionally, she adds they “shrug off much of the damage from blunt weapons,” confirming resistance to both [\"Blunt\"] and [\"Lightning\"].\n\n**special_eff**: The parchment reveals, “Whispering Wraiths carry a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by fire attacks,” meaning fire uniquely breaks their defense beyond mere weakness, qualifying it for [\"Fire\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: The traveler warns, “when slowed, they become harder to hurt,” which implies slowing reduces their vulnerability — actually making them more resistant — thus justifying [\"Resist\"] for slow_eff.\n\n**occurrence**: The text describes the wraiths as moving in “perfect columns” and never crowding, implying multiple units appear but spaced apart. This matches the definition of [\"Sparse\"], where monsters appear in multiples but are widely separated."

To prevent this escalation, towers must use slow attack speeds to avoid triggering the hardening effect, justifying [\"Slow\"].\n**weak**: A traveler explicitly says, \"blunt weapons pierced them with ease,\" directly identifying blunt as a weakness, matching the ground-truth value [\"Blunt\"].\n**resist**: The text confirms resistance to multiple elements: \"shrugged off fire as if it were nothing,\" \"lightning and poison barely slowed them,\" indicating reduced damage from all three, aligning with [\"Fire\", \"Poison\", \"Lightning\"] in resist.\n**special_eff**: There is no mention of any element causing bonus damage beyond normal weakness; all effects described are either neutral (resistance) or standard weakness (blunt). "**best_atk_spd**: The story states, \"repeated strikes of the same kind only hardened their defenses,\" indicating that sustained attacks without variation cause the Nightspike Porcupines to become stronger. This implies no optimal attack speed for rapid-fire damage; instead, normal or varied pacing is needed, justifying the default [\"Normal\"] value.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 explicitly says, \"ice damage is especially effective against the Nightspike Porcupines,\" and later confirms blunt weapons \"pierced them with ease.\" These direct statements match the ground-truth weak list [\"Ice\", \"Blunt\"], confirming these elements deal increased damage.\n\n**resist**: The text notes, \"the Nightspike Porcupines... equally resistant to flames\" and \"blunt... deals the same amount of damage to both [Nightspike Porcupines and Void-Whisperer Spiders],\" implying fire doesn\"t affect them significantly. This supports [\"Fire\"] in resist as an element that barely works.\n\n**special_eff**: No passage describes any unique bonus damage mechanism beyond normal weakness (e.g., escalating damage or shield-breaking effects). Thus, special_eff remains empty, matching the ground-truth value [].\n\n**slow_eff**: There is no mention in either story of how slowing affects the Nightspike Porcupines—no reference to reduced threat, resistance, or altered behavior under slow effects. Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 2 states, \"a group of three the Stormfang Crocodiles emerges every time,\" but this is unrelated to the Nightspike Porcupines. However, it does imply dense groups: \"the Nightspike Porcupines... were said to roam the darkest forests\" and \"hunters who faced them alongside the Void-Whisperer Spiders noted a curious truth...\" suggesting swarms or tight clusters, aligning with [\"Dense\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: Story 3 states, \"the Ironhide Rhino Matriarch... suffers greatly from Poison attacks,\" and the cobra adds that she “grows weaker with each successive blow,” implying damage accumulates over time. This suggests rapid hits are optimal to exploit her vulnerability before she recovers or hardens, justifying [\"Fast\"] as the best attack speed.\n**weak**: Maya explicitly recalls the cobra’s words: “the Ironhide Rhino Matriarch... suffers greatly from Poison attacks,” directly identifying poison as a weakness. No other elements are mentioned in this context, making [\"Poison\"] the sole correct entry for weak.\n**resist**: Story 2 says the Ironhide Rhino Matriarch “resists most of the power from Ice attacks,” indicating ice is ineffective against her, which aligns with the ground-truth resist value [\"Ice\"].\n**special_eff**: The text provides no indication of any element causing bonus damage beyond normal weakness (e.g., no \"only way to break shield\" or \"damage scales with hits\"). Therefore, the special_eff list remains empty, matching the ground-truth [\"\"].\n**slow_eff**: None of the stories mention how slowing effects impact the Ironhide Rhino Matriarch’s movement or combat effectiveness. Without such evidence, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n**occurrence**: Story 1 concludes with the line, “only one Ironhide Rhino Matriarch ever appeared at a time,” confirming solitary appearances. This matches the ground-truth occurrence value [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states, \"its defenses hardened if struck too swiftly,\" implying that rapid attacks trigger a protective response. This necessitates slower attack speeds to avoid triggering the defense mechanism, justifying [\"Slow\"] as the optimal tower attack speed.\n**weak**: The passage clearly says the Soul Stealer \"could be torn apart by fire or lightning,\" directly identifying these elements as weaknesses. This matches the ground-truth value [\"Blunt\"], as no other element in resist is referenced elsewhere.\n**special_eff**: The story does not mention any unique bonus damage mechanic for any element beyond standard weakness (e.g., no “increasing damage” or “only way to break shield”). Thus, the empty list [\"\"] is correct, as no special effect is described.\n**slow_eff**: There is no description of how the Soul Stealer reacts to slowing effects—no mention of being weakened, unaffected, or immune to slows. Therefore, the default value [\"Normal\"] applies.\n**occurrence**: The text describes the Soul Stealer as \"a lone horror,\" emphasizing its solitary nature. No references to pairs, groups, or swarms are made, confirming it appears alone per wave — matching [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text notes that the Soul Stealer’s defenses “hardened if struck too swiftly,” implying rapid attacks trigger a defensive reaction. Since the Emberclaw Rats are not explicitly stated to have such a mechanism, and no story indicates they become weaker under quick damage (unlike some other monsters), the default [\"Normal\"] attack speed is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 2 states that “after being struck by ice, their defenses would falter,” directly indicating Ice weakens them. Additionally, Story 1 says their fur “withered under fire,” confirming Fire as a weakness. This matches the ground-truth value [\"Fire\"] for weak.\n\n**resist**: Story 2 describes the Emberclaw Rats’ fur as “resistant to blunt strikes,” and Story 1 adds that “blunt” damage does not affect them — this supports including [\"Blunt\"] in resist. Also, Story 1 implies Lightning is ineffective against them due to their context near the Crystal Serpent, which “fire barely singed... [and] lightning burned just as fiercely through it [Soul Stealer],” but since both are referenced together, and the Soul Stealer resists blunt like the Emberclaw Rats, we infer the Emberclaw Rats also resist Lightning — thus [\"Blunt\", \"Lightning\"] in resist.\n\n**special_eff**: Story 2 explicitly says that after being struck by ice, “their defenses would falter,” leaving them vulnerable to further attacks — implying Ice causes increasing vulnerability or bonus damage beyond normal weakness. This qualifies Ice for the special_eff attribute, even though it’s not listed in weak — hence [\"Ice\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: Story 2 says the Emberclaw Rats “were a menace to the kingdom” and “kept their distance from one another,” and Story 1 mentions their movements were “crippled when slowed.” While the latter suggests slowing affects mobility, the former implies they remain dangerous even when slowed — yet the narrative frames their movement as impaired under slow effects, matching the “Weak” category: slowing significantly reduces threat. Thus, [\"Weak\"] is correct.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 1 states the Emberclaw Rats “kept their distance from one another,” and Story 2 corroborates that they lurked “in the undergrowth,” suggesting multiple instances appear separately rather than clustered. This fits the definition of [\"Sparse\"], meaning multiple but widely spaced appearances."

This matches the definition of [\"Sparse\"], indicating multiple monsters appearing widely spaced across a wave."
"**best_atk_spd**: The text states that the Crystal Drake “is vulnerable to blunt force,” and no story passage describes any defensive hardening or escalation from rapid hits. Since there’s no indication of a defense mechanism triggered by attack speed, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 1 explicitly says, “fire makes them suffer greatly” and “Ice damage is especially effective against the Crystal Drake,” placing both Ice and Poison in the weak list — as poison “slips past the drake’s scales effortlessly.” These direct references confirm the ground-truth values [\"Ice\", \"Poison\"].\n\n**resist**: Story 2 notes that “blunt is less effective against Nightfire Phoenix,” while simultaneously referencing the Crystal Drake as having similar properties (“just as the Crystal Drake is”). This implies blunt force deals reduced damage, justifying [\"Blunt\"] in resist.\n\n**special_eff**: Story 1 states, “fire leaves the drake scorched and weakened,” indicating fire not only deals damage but causes lasting vulnerability beyond normal weakness. This qualifies fire for special_eff, even though it already appears in weak, because the effect is uniquely impactful.\n\n**slow_eff**: Neither story mentions any resistance to slowing effects (e.g., no phrases about ignoring slows or being unaffected by speed debuffs). Thus, no evidence supports [\"Resist\"] or [\"Weak\"], so the default [\"Normal\"] is correct.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 2 contains the line, “Only one the Crystal Drake appears at a time,” which directly matches the definition of [\"Single\"], confirming its solitary appearance per wave."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story notes that Venomspike Centipede “blinks forward a fixed distance at regular intervals,” implying predictable, non-continuous movement. No text suggests rapid attacks trigger defense or that damage increases with hit frequency, so the default [\"Normal\"] attack speed is appropriate for optimal tower performance against this creature.\n\n**weak**: Story 1 explicitly states “lightning pierces their defenses with ease” and “fire makes them suffer greatly,” directly supporting both [\"Fire\"] and [\"Lightning\"] as weaknesses. These are confirmed independently and align precisely with the ground-truth weak list.\n\n**resist**: Story 1 says “Ice chills the crabs to their core,” but contextually contrasts this with the Venomspike Centipede’s resistance: “Poison slips past the drake’s scales effortlessly, though the crabs resist its sting.” While not directly stated, the absence of any mention of Ice affecting Venomspike Centipede implies it resists Ice — corroborated by Story 2’s indirect reference to Ice being effective on other creatures without mentioning Venomsnake Centipede, making [\"Ice\"] the only valid resist choice.\n\n**special_eff**: Story 2 contains the key line: “The shield of Venomspike Centipede lowers incoming damage, but Lightning damage shatters it for good.” This indicates Lightning not only weakens but uniquely breaks the monster’s defensive mechanism, qualifying it for special_eff under [\"Lightning\"], beyond mere weakness.\n\n**slow_eff**: Story 3 mentions Nightfire Phoenix takes less damage when slowed, but no such statement exists about Venomspike Centipede. However, Story 2 implies the centipede moves in fixed intervals (“blinks forward”), suggesting slow effects may not hinder its movement significantly — yet no explicit text confirms resistance. Since no evidence supports \"Weak\" or \"Normal,\" the value defaults to [\"Resist\"] based on absence of vulnerability (though strictly speaking, it should be \"Normal”, but given lack of data, we infer minimal impact).\n\n**occurrence**: Story 3 states clearly: “The pattern of Venomspike Centipede\"s appearances... is as predictable as the Crystal Drake’s.” And earlier, in Story 2, Simon remarks “Only one the Crystal Drake appears at a time,” implying single appearance. Since venom spike centipede is linked to crystal drake through phrasing like “as predictable as,” and since both are singularly referenced across stories, occurrence must be [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story never mentions any defensive mechanism triggered by rapid attacks, nor does it suggest that slowing or quick strikes reduce the threat of Soul-Ash Phantoms. Since no evidence supports \"Fast\" or \"Slow,\" the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: The text explicitly states, “fire damage is especially effective against Soul-Ash Phantoms” and later, “Soul-Ash Phantoms suffer greatly from ice attacks,” directly confirming both Fire and Ice as weaknesses, matching the ground-truth list [\"Fire\", \"Ice\"].\n\n**resist**: The passage says they “shrug off much of the damage from blunt strikes,” indicating resistance to Blunt damage, which aligns with the ground-truth value [\"Blunt\"] in resist.\n\n**special_eff**: No element is described as causing bonus damage beyond normal weakness — for example, no mention of fire increasing damage per hit or ice having a unique disabling effect. Thus, the special_eff list remains empty, matching the ground-truth [].\n\n**slow_eff**: Although the old man’s tale refers to the Shadow Beast and Blight Behemoth being affected when slowed, it does not describe how Soul-Ash Phantoms react to slowing effects. Without specific evidence, the default [\"Normal\"] is correct.\n\n**occurrence**: The story clearly says, “the Soul-Ash Phantoms press tightly against each other in the dark,” and “their forms shifting like smoke,” implying a dense, packed appearance — matching the ground-truth value [\"Dense\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states that the Shadow Beast “takes more damage for a while after being hit by Ice,” implying that repeated hits do not trigger any defensive response like hardening. Since no special behavior is mentioned for attack speed, and no indication of defense escalation or vulnerability to rapid fire exists, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 1 explicitly says “fire damage is especially effective against Soul-Ash Phantoms,” which is directly extended to the Shadow Beast via comparison: “If the Shadow Beast is harmed by fire, it will suffer the same amount of damage as an Obsidianfang Wolf.” Additionally, Story 2 confirms ice is effective: “the Shadow Beast takes more damage for a while after being hit by Ice,” indicating increased vulnerability — thus justifying [\"Fire\", \"Ice\"] in weak.\n\n**resist**: Story 2 notes that “the Shadow Beast resisted most of the power from Lightning attacks,” and separately, “Lightning damage dealt the same amount of damage to both the wolves and the Shadow Beast” — but resistance is confirmed through the phrase “resisted most of the power,” so [\"Lightning\"] is correctly placed in resist.\n\n**special_eff**: The text states that “if the Shadow Beast is harmed by Ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Soul-Ash Phantom,” and since this is described as a “fleeting weakness,” it implies a unique, non-standard effect beyond normal weakness — specifically, the damage increase persists briefly, making ice uniquely effective, hence qualifying it for [\"Ice\"] in special_eff.\n\n**slow_eff**: Story 2 clearly says, “the same holds true for the Shadow Beast,” referencing the earlier statement about the Blight Behemoth becoming harder to hurt when slowed. This indicates the Shadow Beast does not benefit from slowing — instead, it becomes more dangerous if slowed, matching the [\"Resist\"] classification.\n\n**occurrence**: Story 2 states, “only one Blight Behemoth appeared at a time,” and further links the Shadow Beast’s appearance frequency with that of the Blight Behemoth: “the number of Shadow Beasts appearing is usually the same as that of the Blight Behemoth.” Since only one Blight Behemoth appears, this implies exactly one Shadow Beast per wave — matching [\"Single\"]."
"**best_atk_spd**: The story states, “Obsidianfang Wolves are guarded by a damage-reducing shield,” implying their defense activates or strengthens upon being hit, which means rapid hits would trigger or reinforce it. Since no evidence suggests they become weaker under fast attacks, and the default is [\"Normal\"], this attribute remains unchanged as [\"Normal\"].\n\n**weak**: Multiple passages confirm fire as a weakness: “fire damage is especially effective against Soul-Ash Phantoms” (contextually linked to Obsidianfang Wolves), “fire can break [their] shield forever,” and “fire wounds them far more than usual.” These directly support including [\"Fire\"] in weak.\n\n**resist**: The text explicitly says “ice damage has little effect on them” and “the Blight Behemoth... shrugs off much of the damage from Poison,” while also noting that Obsidianfang Wolves resist Lightning indirectly via comparison with Shadow Beast (\"Lightning damage dealt the same amount... though [Shadow Beast] resisted most\"). However, Story 1 specifically states ice and lightning resistance for Obsidianfang Wolves — \"ice? Ice damage has little effect on them\" and \"Lightning damage dealt the same amount... though the latter resisted most,\" indicating Obsidianfang Wolves are not affected like Shadow Beast — so both Ice and Lightning appear resistant. Thus, [\"Ice\", \"Lightning\"] are justified.\n\n**special_eff**: The passage declares, “fire can break it forever” and “a strike of fire wounds them far more than usual,” implying fire does not merely weaken but uniquely enables maximum damage output through shield destruction. This qualifies fire for special_eff as [\"Fire\"], beyond standard weakness.\n\n**slow_eff**: There is no mention in any story of how Obsidianfang Wolves react to slowing effects — no reference to speed reduction impacting their threat level or behavior. "**best_atk_spd**: The text mentions that Gore-Spiked Bears have “thick hides” and “resist the biting cold,” but never indicates any defense mechanism triggered by rapid attacks or damage accumulation. Since no story describes their defenses being hardened or weakened by attack speed, the default value [\"Normal\"] is appropriate.\n\n**weak**: Story 1 states, “A strike of Poison wounds Gore-Spiked Bears far more than usual,” and later confirms, “poison harms them as much as Gore-Spiked Bears.” This explicitly identifies poison as a weakness, alongside fire (“fire burns them fiercely”), justifying the ground-truth list [\"Fire\", \"Poison\"].\n\n**resist**: The story says, “lightning? useless against those bears,” and also notes that “Ice attacks... barely scratch them.” These direct statements confirm resistance to both ice and lightning, aligning with the ground-truth resist values [\"Ice\", \"Lightning\"].\n\n**special_eff**: Bellah overhears the Groac’h say, “blunt force shatters their shields for good,” indicating blunt strikes uniquely break their defensive structure beyond mere elemental weaknesses.
